awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Apple Yield Mapping using Computer Vision
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to use the proposed system for automation of yield mapping so that growers will be able to improve their growing and harvesting processes. Yield mapping is critical for fruit growers. An accurate estimate is enormously beneficial to sales operations, harvest time logistics, and crop management. Currently, yield mapping is performed manually in a difficult, laborious process prone to sampling and counting error. The proposed system would enable growers to sell better fruit at higher prices while using less resources. By bringing improved certainty to harvest quantity and timing, the system will also improve the efficiency of the entire fruit supply chain, making fresh fruit more readily available in stores at more consistent prices.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will address the problem of automated yield mapping for fruit crops. Rather than relying on expensive sensing equipment such as laser-based lidar scanners, the company proposes to build a robust, yet inexpensive, fruit mapping system using commercial, off-the-shelf components. In order to achieve this goal, significant computer vision and systems challenges must be overcome. These include: (1) Adapting and developing accurate computer vision algorithms for fruit detection and segmentation, as well as geometric algorithms for sizing and tracking fruit and mapping the foliage; and (2) Building usable and reliable systems for scanning, upload, cloud processing, and results visualization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview:

Farm Vision Technologies, a startup company based in St. Paul, MN, studied the problem of accurate apple yield prediction using advanced computer vision techniques. The aim was to develop a system capable of counting and sizing fruits on trees. While the primary focus was apples, tests were also conducted on oranges and stone fruits. By the end of the grant period, the system had been adopted by several apple orchards.

Outcomes and Innovations:

During the course of this SBIR Phase II project, Farm Vision was able to make substantial improvements to the system to help it better meet the needs of fruit growers.  Most notably:

  • Farm Vision made the system fully autonomously usable by the customer. The user can perform scans using a phone app, push a button to upload, and view the scan results on an internet dashboard. These results include count, size, color, thinning forecasts, and yield forecasts. Customers have used these results to make important decisions about managing their orchards.
  • Farm Vision simplified the scanning hardware. Previously the system required setting up an RTK GPS base station, but by the end of the project the system received optional RTK corrections over the cell phone network. Farm Vision integrated a depth sensor to improve scale accuracy and reduce reliance on RTK, and dropped the requirement for a gimbal, fitting everything in a single scanner unit with a built-in battery and heatsink. Overall the system was much easier for customers to use.
  • Farm Vision developed a remote controller app so that the sensor system could be controlled while mounted on a vehicle.
  • Farm Vision achieved detection of blossoms and fruitlets, early in the growing season. The Farm Vision system automatically matches fruitlets across different scans and applies the Greene Fruit Growth Model, to predict fruitlet persistence rate.
  • Farm Vision substantially improved the count and size accuracy of the scan results.

 

Broader Impacts:

The system offers several benefits to apple growers:

  • Thinning Optimization: Early determination of apple crop load allows growers to improve their yield and fruit quality through improved fruit thinning.
  • Sales Planning: Detailed yield and fruit size projections allows for more strategic sales planning, potentially leading to improved market prices.
  • Harvest Logistics: The system's data aids in efficient harvest planning, from fruit picking to storage and packaging.

With the assistance of this SBIR Phase II award, Farm Vision Technologies has made a significant contribution to the integration of technology in fruit production. This project not only benefits individual orchards but also has potential implications for the broader food and agricultural sector.


Last Modified: 10/24/2023
Modified by: Patrick A Plonski
